Title: Bulgarian Bulgargaz EAD seeks gas supplies for December delivery
Description: Bulgaria’s national gas supplier Bulgargaz EAD is looking to buy 13,540 MWh a day of gas (2 m m3) to be delivered in December through an auction on the Balkan Gas Hub exchange market on Nov. 7. Bulgaria has been seeking additional gas and LNG supplies since April when it stopped receiving pipeline gas supplies from Russia, which used to be its main supplier.
Author: DE

Title: UK’s largest gas storage reopens at 20% capacity for this winter
Description: The UK’s largest gas storage facility, Rough, has reopened and will operate at 20% of its previous capacity this winter. The facility could store up to 850 m m3 this winter, which is the equivalent of nine LNG cargos of 165,000 m3
Author: DE

Title: Spain boosts pipeline capacity to France, giving the EU greater access to LNG import capacity
Description: Pipeline capacity from Spain to France will increase by 1.5 bn m3 a year or 18% of the total capacity from Spain to France from Nov. 1. This will give the rest of EU countries, particularly those without terminals of their own, greater access to LNG import capacity
Author: DE

Title: Germany’s privately funded Lubmin FSRU fully booked, confirmed for December commissioning
Description: All the marketed long-term regasification capacities at Germany’s privately-funded Lubmin FSRU have been booked. Set to come online on Dec. 1, this will be Germany's first of six LNG import terminals aimed to end its reliance on Russian pipeline gas
Author: DE

Title: Japan’s JBIC provides second loan to Jera for LNG imports
Description: The Japan Bank of International Cooperation, or JBIC, said today that it has extended a loan of 100 billion Japanese yen (around $676 m) to Japan’s largest LNG buyer and power generation firm Jera to secure LNG supplies amid rising prices and a need for stable electricity supply.
Author: CK

Title: Term buyers expect no Bintulu LNG term cargo cancellations this winter despite pipeline leak
Description: Term offtakers expect to receive all their contracted cargoes from the MLNG Dua project at the Petronas-operated 29.3 mtpa Bintulu LNG export complex in Malaysia this winter, following assurances from the Malaysian state-owned firm that it intends to use alternative sources of gas and LNG to compensate for the lost flows from the Sabah-Sarawak gas pipeline.
Author: CK
